content.justification: The use of 'will work cooperatively' indicates a clear obligation on the supplier to facilitate the process, which is highly desirable for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Ensures the supplier's active participation in making the assignment process efficient.
content.implication_supplier: Obligates the supplier to provide reasonable assistance during the transition period.
content.source_insight: A practical clause to ensure the operational aspects of an assignment are handled effectively.
content.text: [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.

content.verbatim_text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.
content.plain_text: Assignment clauses are crucial in M&A scenarios. Requiring consent for assignment can complicate transactions and create leverage for the non-transferring party to demand concessions.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the strategic importance of proactive negotiation on assignment clauses. A poorly drafted clause can turn into a significant deal-breaker or cost-adder during a corporate transaction, giving the counterparty undue power.
content.justification: Provides general background information and potential risks associated with assignment clauses in M&A contexts.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must prioritize clear and flexible assignment rights in its contracts to avoid future complications and potential extortion during M&A or reorganization.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may gain unexpected leverage if Zebracorp's contracts require their consent for assignment, potentially allowing them to demand concessions.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly warns about the 'opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions'.
content.text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.

content.verbatim_text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level). In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should aim for maximum flexibility to assign contracts without supplier consent, especially to succeeding entities (reorganization) or affiliates. If full flexibility is not achievable, a fallback position is to ensure consent cannot be 'arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed'.
content.expert_insight: This sets a clear negotiation objective for Zebracorp: secure broad assignment rights. The 'not unreasonably withheld' clause is a common compromise, but Zebracorp's primary goal should be automatic assignment for internal restructuring or M&A.
content.justification: Provides direct strategic advice and a fallback position for negotiating assignment clauses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp gains operational agility for reorganizations and M&A by securing flexible assignment rights, minimizing legal hurdles and costs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will be expected to agree to broad assignment rights for Zebracorp, potentially limiting their control over who they contract with indirectly.
content.source_insight: The text outlines both the ideal scenario ('maximum flexibility') and a pragmatic compromise ('not arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld').
content.text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level). In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.

content.verbatim_text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially. Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should explicitly negotiate for the right to partially assign contracts and, ideally, to 'split' contracts. This ensures flexibility for divesting business lines, allowing both Zebracorp and the acquirer to continue using the same contract.
content.expert_insight: This is forward-thinking advice for managing complex corporate structures and divestitures. Explicitly stating partial assignment and contract splitting avoids ambiguity and potential disputes, which is critical for maintaining business continuity post-transaction.
content.justification: Provides specific negotiation points to ensure maximum flexibility for future corporate actions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp secures greater flexibility for business line divestments, ensuring continuity of critical contracts for both itself and potential acquirers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may face more complex contract management if agreements can be partially assigned or split, requiring them to potentially deal with multiple entities under one original contract.
content.source_insight: The text distinguishes between implicit rights and recommended explicit agreement for clarity.
content.text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially. Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent. This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should generally refuse mutual assignment rights, even if it means foregoing its own assignment right. The rationale is that suppliers are selected based on specific criteria, and allowing them to freely assign would undermine this selection process and potentially jeopardize critical commitments.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical strategic stance for Zebracorp, prioritizing supplier vetting and performance over its own reciprocal assignment flexibility. It emphasizes the customer's need to control who provides services, especially for critical functions.
content.justification: Outlines a key negotiation strategy and provides the underlying business justification for it.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains control over the identity and qualifications of its suppliers, protecting its supply chain and contractual commitments.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will likely be restricted from freely assigning their contracts, potentially limiting their own M&A or restructuring options without Zebracorp's explicit consent.
content.source_insight: The text clearly states a preference to 'forego our right to assign' rather than grant mutual rights, highlighting the strength of this position.
content.text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent. This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.

content.verbatim_text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's assignment rights should ensure a 'clean exit', meaning Zebracorp is not jointly liable for the assigned contract with the assignee and does not accept liability for the assignee's commitments.
content.expert_insight: This is crucial for liability mitigation. Zebracorp aims to fully transfer both benefits and burdens, ensuring it's not left with residual obligations or contingent liabilities after an assignment.
content.justification: Provides a clear instruction on how to structure assignment clauses to mitigate Zebracorp's post-assignment liability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp minimizes its long-term liability exposure post-assignment, ensuring a complete transfer of obligations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will need to accept that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable after an assignment, shifting full responsibility to the new contracting party.
content.source_insight: The phrase 'clean exit' clearly encapsulates the desired outcome regarding liability.
content.text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.

content.verbatim_text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open. An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party. The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.
content.plain_text: This section provides context on M&A transaction structures and their impact on contract assignment. Acquiring a company's shares or merging generally avoids the need for contract-by-contract assignment consents, as the legal entity holding the contracts remains the same, only its ownership changes. This 'assignment by operation of law' typically does not require consent, though parties can contractually agree otherwise for significant ownership changes.
content.expert_insight: This is crucial background information for Zebracorp's M&A strategy. Understanding the legal distinction between asset sales (requiring assignment) and share acquisitions/mergers (often not requiring assignment) allows for more efficient transaction planning and negotiation of assignment clauses.
content.justification: Provides detailed contextual information about different M&A structures and their implications for contract assignment, including the concept of 'assignment by operation of law'.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can strategically structure its acquisitions to minimize the need for individual contract consents, streamlining M&A processes and reducing associated costs and delays.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that their contracts with Zebracorp may transfer automatically by operation of law in certain M&A scenarios, even without their explicit consent, unless specific change of control clauses are in place.
content.source_insight: The text clarifies a common misconception about changes in ownership and consent requirements.
content.text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open. An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party. The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.

content.verbatim_text: Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates. Zebracorp also has such ownership clauses in some of its supplier contracts, most notably in the R&D related contracts where the identity of the party doing development work can be an important factor. While we may want to restrict the supplier from changing ownership or control without our approval, Zebracorp is often not itself willing to agree to such restrictions.
content.plain_text: Change of control clauses, which prohibit transfers by merger or operation of law without consent, are common, especially in supplier templates. While Zebracorp uses such clauses in its critical R&D contracts to restrict suppliers, it is generally unwilling to accept similar restrictions on itself.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a strategic asymmetry in Zebracorp's approach. It acknowledges the need for control over critical suppliers but resists reciprocal restrictions, indicating a strong negotiating position based on its customer status.
content.justification: Provides context on the prevalence of restrictive clauses and Zebracorp's internal stance on applying them mutually.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains flexibility for its own corporate transactions while imposing restrictions on critical suppliers, reflecting its strategic priorities.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may encounter non-mutual change of control clauses, where Zebracorp restricts their ability to transfer contracts but expects its own transfers to be unrestricted.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states 'Zebracorp is often not itself willing to agree to such restrictions', indicating a non-mutual approach.
content.text: Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates. Zebracorp also has such ownership clauses in some of its supplier contracts, most notably in the R&D related contracts where the identity of the party doing development work can be an important factor. While we may want to restrict the supplier from changing ownership or control without our approval, Zebracorp is often not itself willing to agree to such restrictions.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction. In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's firm stance is to reject clauses requiring consent for assignment by operation of law, as these complicate M&A. In critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes such restrictions on suppliers, it would rather remove the clause entirely than agree to a mutual restriction. This non-mutuality can be justified by the customer-supplier asymmetry. A potential concession to suppliers is to allow assignment by operation of law to non-competitors.
content.expert_insight: This outlines Zebracorp's strong, non-negotiable position on assignment by operation of law for its own benefit, while providing a strategic justification and a potential compromise for suppliers. It balances Zebracorp's need for M&A flexibility with practical supplier relations.
content.justification: Provides a firm negotiation stance, its rationale, a strategic trade-off for critical contracts, an argument for non-mutuality, and a potential concession.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp ensures its M&A activities are not hindered by supplier consent requirements, maintaining strategic flexibility. It also provides a clear framework for negotiating with suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will face resistance to clauses restricting Zebracorp's assignment by operation of law. They might be offered a limited right to assign to non-competitors as a compromise.
content.source_insight: The text provides both the 'firm view' and practical 'explanation' and 'concession' strategies.
content.text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction. In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language. Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.
content.plain_text: Under UK law, transferring both benefits and burdens of a contract typically requires novation, not just assignment, to avoid residual liability. For UK-governed agreements, explicitly mention novation and consult Legal & Compliance for templates. While 'novation' is often used loosely in other jurisdictions, it's generally understood to mean contract transfer.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical legal nuance for contracts governed by UK law, ensuring a complete transfer of obligations and liabilities. The instruction to consult Legal & Compliance is a vital internal process step to ensure correct legal execution.
content.justification: Provides specific legal guidance and an internal process instruction for contracts under UK law, along with general information about the term 'novation'.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure proper legal procedures (novation) are followed for UK-governed contracts to achieve a clean transfer of both rights and obligations, avoiding unintended residual liabilities.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers dealing with Zebracorp under UK law will need to understand and comply with novation requirements for full contract transfer.
content.source_insight: Highlights the distinction between assignment and novation under UK law and addresses common misuses of the term 'novation'.
content.text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language. Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.

content.verbatim_text: Companies have the freedom to change the trade name that they use to conduct their business. When changing the name of the company, the registered legal entity which can be identified through each company’s individual registration number remains the same. These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes. Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”
content.plain_text: Changes to a company's trade name or registered address are not considered assignments if the underlying legal entity (identified by its registration number) remains the same. Therefore, no consent is required; a unilateral notification is sufficient. While clarifying in future amendments is recommended, it's not strictly necessary, and a 'formerly known as' notation can be used.
content.expert_insight: This provides practical guidance on a common administrative change, clarifying that it does not trigger assignment clauses. It streamlines internal processes by confirming that formal consent is not needed, only notification.
content.justification: Clarifies the legal distinction between a company name/address change and an assignment, providing practical instructions for handling such changes.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can change its name or address without needing to seek consent from all its contract counterparties, simplifying administrative processes.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp's name or address changes do not constitute an assignment requiring their consent, and a simple notification is sufficient.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states 'strictly speaking this is not necessary' regarding contract amendments, offering flexibility.

content.verbatim_text: An assignment clause determines whether the rights, obligations and duties under a particular contract may be transferred in whole or in part to another third party, and under what conditions.
content.plain_text: An assignment clause is a contractual provision that determines if and under what conditions the rights, obligations, and duties of a contract can be transferred to a third party.
content.expert_insight: This definition highlights the core function of an assignment clause, which is to control the transferability of contractual elements. It also implicitly points to the strategic importance of these clauses in transactions like sales or acquisitions, as further elaborated in the surrounding text.
content.text: An assignment clause determines whether the rights, obligations and duties under a particular contract may be transferred in whole or in part to another third party, and under what conditions.

content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract.
content.plain_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights in a contract typically only allows for the transfer of the benefits of the contract, not the burdens or obligations.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial distinction for UK-governed contracts, as it implies that a simple 'assignment' may not fully transfer all liabilities, necessitating a novation for a complete transfer of both benefits and burdens.
content.text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract.

content.verbatim_text: Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.
content.plain_text: Requiring consent for contract assignment can complicate or derail transactions, and a poorly negotiated clause can lead to extortion by the non-transferring party.

content.verbatim_text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's contracts should allow maximum flexibility to assign without supplier consent to a succeeding entity (reorganization) or, at minimum, allow free assignment to an affiliate (for share purchase reorganization).
content.expert_insight: This guideline is crucial for Zebracorp to maintain operational flexibility and facilitate corporate restructuring without being hindered by individual supplier contracts.
content.conditions: Applies to all contracts Zebracorp concludes.
content.justification: Ensures smooth reorganization and acquisition processes, preventing complications and potential extortion from contract parties.
content.implication_company: Ensures smooth reorganization and acquisition processes without needing supplier consent, reducing transaction costs and delays.
content.implication_supplier: May be required to accept assignment to Zebracorp's affiliates or successor entities without their consent, potentially altering the counterparty they contract with.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.
content.plain_text: If a supplier refuses to allow assignment to an affiliate, the contract should state that approval for assignment will not be "arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed."
content.expert_insight: This provides a crucial fallback position, ensuring that even if direct consent isn't granted, the supplier cannot block assignments without a valid, reasonable commercial reason.
content.conditions: If a supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant Zebracorp the right to assign to an affiliate.
content.justification: Provides a fallback position to prevent arbitrary blocking of assignments, ensuring some level of flexibility for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Provides a fallback position to prevent arbitrary blocking of assignments, maintaining some control over transferability.
content.implication_supplier: Cannot unreasonably deny consent for assignment if this clause is included, requiring them to have a justifiable reason for withholding approval.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.

content.verbatim_text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should ensure its contracts explicitly allow for partial assignment, even if it's often implicitly covered by the right to assign the entire agreement.
content.expert_insight: Explicitly stating partial assignment rights removes ambiguity and provides clearer contractual grounds for transferring only specific parts of a contract, which can be vital in complex transactions.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Provides clear contractual basis for assigning only parts of a contract, offering greater flexibility for business operations and divestments.
content.implication_company: Provides clear contractual basis for assigning only parts of a contract, offering greater flexibility in managing specific business lines or assets.
content.implication_supplier: Must accept partial assignments if explicitly agreed, potentially leading to managing split contractual obligations.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially.

content.verbatim_text: Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should aim to secure the right to 'split' contracts for divestment scenarios, allowing both Zebracorp and an acquirer of a business line to continue using the contract.
content.expert_insight: This ensures business continuity for both parties after a divestment, preventing disruption and the need to renegotiate or establish new contracts for the divested business line.
content.conditions: In case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line.
content.justification: Facilitates divestments by ensuring continuity of contracts for both the divesting and acquiring entities, minimizing disruption.
content.implication_company: Facilitates divestments by ensuring continuity of contracts for both the divesting and acquiring entities, reducing complexity and potential loss of contractual benefits.
content.implication_supplier: May need to manage a single contract split into two separate relationships following a divestment, requiring administrative adjustments.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent. This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not agree to mutual assignment rights with suppliers. It prefers to forgo its own assignment right rather than allowing suppliers to freely assign without Zebracorp's consent, to protect its supplier selection process and prevent suppliers from evading commitments.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk mitigation strategy. Allowing suppliers to freely assign without consent undermines due diligence and exposes Zebracorp to unvetted, potentially unreliable counterparties.
content.conditions: When negotiating assignment clauses with suppliers/subcontractors.
content.justification: Supplier selection process ensures financial and operational capability; free assignment by supplier negates this and risks evasion of commitments.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from having unvetted third parties as suppliers and ensures continuity of critical commitments, mitigating supply chain risks.
content.implication_supplier: Will likely not have the right to freely assign their contracts without Zebracorp's consent, limiting their flexibility in transferring obligations.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent. This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.

content.verbatim_text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's right to assign should not require it to remain jointly liable with the assignee. The assignment must be unconditional, providing a clean exit where Zebracorp accepts no liability for the assignee's commitments.
content.expert_insight: This is fundamental for risk management. Retaining joint liability after assignment defeats the purpose of transferring the contract and keeps Zebracorp exposed to the assignee's performance.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Ensures a clean break from contractual obligations post-assignment, mitigating future liability and providing legal certainty.
content.implication_company: Ensures a clean break from contractual obligations post-assignment, mitigating future liability and reducing long-term risk exposure.
content.implication_supplier: Will deal solely with the assignee after assignment, without recourse to Zebracorp for assignee's failures, shifting full responsibility to the new party.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.

content.verbatim_text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale.
content.plain_text: In acquisitions, parties choose between buying assets (requiring specific assignment of each desired contract) or acquiring the entire company. Asset sales necessitate detailed contract-by-contract due diligence for assignment.

content.text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale.

content.verbatim_text: The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.
content.plain_text: Acquiring a company's share capital or merging generally avoids the need for contract assignment consents because the legal entity holding the contracts remains the same, only its ownership changes.

This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.

content.verbatim_text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party.
content.plain_text: In most countries, acquisitions or mergers automatically transfer assets, liabilities, and contracts to the surviving entity by "operation of law," without requiring consent from the other contracting party.

content.verbatim_text: The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent. Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon.
content.plain_text: Parties can contractually agree that certain ownership changes (e.g., over 50% of shares) or change of control events will require consent, overriding automatic transfer by operation of law.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's firm view is that assignment by operation of law should not require supplier consent, and it should reject clauses mandating such consent, as these complicate M&A transactions.
content.expert_insight: This guideline is vital for Zebracorp to avoid significant hurdles and potential deal-breaking issues during M&A activities. Negotiating away these restrictions upfront saves considerable time and cost later.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Such provisions are likely to cause complications, impacting timing, cost, and the ability to consummate smooth mergers, acquisitions, or other transactions.
content.implication_company: Aims to streamline M&A processes by avoiding the need for numerous supplier consents, reducing transaction friction and costs.
content.implication_supplier: May find their contracts automatically transferred to a new entity without their consent in the event of a Zebracorp merger or acquisition, potentially changing their counterparty.

This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions.

content.verbatim_text: For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.

An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.

content.verbatim_text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier.
content.plain_text: In critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes assignment restrictions on suppliers, it's better to remove the clause entirely than to make it mutual and restrict Zebracorp. This asymmetry can be justified by the customer-supplier relationship.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the strategic importance of Zebracorp's own flexibility, even at the cost of some control over suppliers in specific high-value contracts. The customer-supplier power dynamic is key to this negotiation stance.
content.conditions: Applies to critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes assignment restrictions on suppliers.
content.justification: Prioritizes Zebracorp's flexibility in assigning contracts over mutual restrictions, particularly given the asymmetric customer-supplier relationship.
content.implication_company: Prioritizes Zebracorp's flexibility over imposing mutual restrictions in critical contracts, even if it means foregoing some control over supplier changes, to ensure its own strategic agility.
content.implication_supplier: May face assignment restrictions in critical R&D contracts, but Zebracorp will resist mutual restrictions on itself, potentially leading to an unequal contractual position.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.

content.expert_insight: This is a good compromise that balances supplier flexibility with Zebracorp's competitive interests, offering a practical solution during negotiations.

content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A

content.text: Companies have the freedom to change the trade name that they use to conduct their business. When changing the name of the company, the registered legal entity which can be identified through each company’s individual registration number remains the same. These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes.

content.verbatim_text: Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”
content.plain_text: Consent is not required for a company name or registered address change; a unilateral notification is sufficient. While clarifying in future amendments is recommended (e.g., using "f/k/a"), it's not strictly necessary.
content.expert_insight: This simplifies administrative processes significantly, avoiding unnecessary consent procedures for purely administrative changes.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Name/address changes do not alter the underlying legal entity, thus not constituting an assignment.
content.implication_company: Simplifies administrative processes for name/address changes, requiring only notification and avoiding the need for formal consent from counterparties.
content.implication_supplier: Must acknowledge name/address changes upon notification, no consent required, but may need to update internal records.
content.source_insight: N/A

content.verbatim_text: “Except as otherwise provided in this [Agreement], neither party may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer this [Agreement], or any of its individual rights or obligations under this [Agreement], without the prior written approval of the other Party, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Any attempted assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer without the necessary approval is void. However, [Zebracorp] may, without the prior written consent of the [Supplier], unconditionally assign, novate, delegate or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations under this [Agreement], in whole, in part, or through a splitting of the [Agreement], to any Affiliate or to any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which this contract relates. As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement], and [Zebracorp] is unconditionally released and discharged from all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement]. [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.”
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred assignment clause allows neither party to assign/novate/delegate/transfer without prior written approval (not unreasonably withheld/delayed), with unauthorized attempts being void. However, Zebracorp can unconditionally assign/novate/delegate/transfer all or part of its rights/obligations, or split the agreement, to any affiliate or acquirer of a relevant business line without supplier consent. Upon such transfer, the assignee assumes all rights/obligations/liabilities, and Zebracorp is unconditionally released. The supplier must cooperate for a smooth transition.
content.expert_insight: This clause is a comprehensive embodiment of Zebracorp's strategic priorities for assignment: mutual reasonable consent as a default, but absolute flexibility for its own internal restructuring and M&A activities, coupled with a clean liability break.
content.conditions: General rule: Mutual consent required, not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Zebracorp exception: Unconditional assignment/novation/delegation/transfer without supplier consent to any Affiliate or acquirer of a relevant Zebracorp business line. Effect of Zebracorp's assignment: Assignee assumes all rights/obligations/liabilities; Zebracorp is unconditionally released. Supplier obligation: Cooperate for smooth transition.
content.justification: Provides Zebracorp maximum flexibility for internal reorganizations, divestments, and acquisitions while protecting it from residual liability, balancing with a general mutual consent requirement.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp's ability to restructure and divest without supplier impediment and provides a clean exit from liabilities, significantly enhancing corporate agility.
content.implication_supplier: Must grant consent for general assignments (not unreasonably withheld), but cannot prevent Zebracorp's assignment to affiliates or business line acquirers and must cooperate with the transition, accepting the new counterparty and Zebracorp's release from liability.
content.source_insight: N/A

content.verbatim_text: An assignment clause determines whether the rights, obligations and duties under a particular contract may be transferred in whole or in part to another third party, and under what conditions.
content.plain_text: An assignment clause defines if and how contractual rights, obligations, and duties can be transferred to a third party.
content.expert_insight: This definition highlights the core function of an assignment clause: to regulate the transferability of a contract's elements. Understanding this is crucial for assessing flexibility and risk.
