content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: An assignment clause determines whether the rights, obligations and duties under a particular contract may be transferred in whole or in part to another third party, and under what conditions.

content.verbatim_text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.
content.plain_text: Assignment clauses are vital in M&A transactions. Requiring consent for assignment can complicate or delay deals, and neglecting clause language during negotiation can lead to future extortion attempts by the non-transferring party for their consent.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the strategic importance of assignment clauses beyond standard contract management. Proactive negotiation is key to avoid future leverage by counterparties, especially in corporate restructuring scenarios.
content.justification: Explains the significance and potential pitfalls of assignment clauses.
content.implication_company: Poorly negotiated assignment clauses can complicate or sidetrack M&A transactions and lead to costly concessions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may gain leverage if assignment clauses are not carefully drafted, potentially extorting concessions for consent.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states the criticality and potential negative outcomes.
content.text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.

content.verbatim_text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should ensure contracts allow maximum flexibility for assignment without supplier consent, especially to succeeding entities during reorganization or to affiliates (covering share purchase acquisitions).
content.expert_insight: This is a core strategic objective for Zebracorp: maintaining flexibility for corporate restructuring without needing individual supplier consents. Prioritizing assignment to affiliates or successor entities is a pragmatic approach.
content.conditions: Assignment to a succeeding entity (reorganization) or an affiliate (share purchase acquisition).
content.justification: To avoid complications and potential sidetracking of transactions, and to maintain flexibility for corporate reorganizations.
content.implication_company: Increased operational flexibility for M&A and reorganizations, reduced administrative burden.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may lose control over who performs the contract if Zebracorp assigns to an affiliate or successor without consent.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states this as an important objective for Zebracorp.
content.text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.
content.plain_text: If a supplier refuses direct assignment to an affiliate, Zebracorp should at least ensure the contract states that any required approval for assignment will not be arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial fallback position. While not ideal, a 'not unreasonably withheld' clause provides some protection against a supplier's arbitrary refusal, forcing them to have legitimate business reasons for denying consent.
content.conditions: Supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant direct right to assign to an affiliate.
content.justification: To prevent arbitrary or unreasonable denial of assignment consent by the supplier, ensuring some level of flexibility.
content.implication_company: Provides a legal basis to challenge unreasonable denials of assignment consent, mitigating risk of transaction delays.
content.implication_supplier: Restricts the supplier's ability to arbitrarily block assignments, requiring them to demonstrate reasonable grounds for refusal.
content.source_insight: The text provides this as a minimum requirement.
content.text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.

content.verbatim_text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially. Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's assignment rights should explicitly include partial assignment. While sometimes implicit, it's recommended to expressly agree on the right to assign in whole or in part. Additionally, Zebracorp should aim to secure the right to 'split' contracts during business line divestments, ensuring both Zebracorp and the acquirer can continue using the contract.
content.expert_insight: Explicitly covering partial assignment and contract splitting is crucial for managing divestitures and ensuring business continuity. Relying on implicit rights can lead to disputes.
content.conditions: Negotiating assignment clauses.
content.justification: To provide maximum flexibility for managing contracts during divestments and reorganizations, ensuring continuity for all relevant parties.
content.implication_company: Enables smoother divestments and business line transfers, reducing the need for renegotiation or new contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may need to manage relationships with multiple entities if a contract is partially assigned or split.
content.source_insight: The text recommends this for optimal flexibility.
content.text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially. Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent.
content.plain_text: When negotiating assignment clauses, Zebracorp should not agree to mutual assignment rights. In most cases, Zebracorp would prefer to waive its own assignment right rather than allow a supplier to freely assign the agreement without Zebracorp's consent.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical defensive position. Mutual assignment rights can expose Zebracorp to unknown or unqualified suppliers, undermining its rigorous selection process. The risk of losing control over the supplier relationship outweighs the benefit of Zebracorp's own assignment flexibility in this specific context.
content.conditions: Negotiating assignment clauses with suppliers/subcontractors.
content.justification: To protect Zebracorp from having an unvetted third party substitute for a selected supplier, which could negate the supplier selection process and lead to critical contractual commitments being unfulfilled.
content.implication_company: Maintains control over the quality and reliability of its supplier base, preventing potential disruptions and risks from unknown third-party assignees.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will be restricted from freely assigning their contracts, potentially limiting their own flexibility in corporate transactions.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states this as a preference and provides a strong justification.
content.text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent.

content.verbatim_text: This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.
content.plain_text: The rationale for not allowing suppliers free assignment is that Zebracorp's suppliers are vetted for financial and operational capability. Unrestricted assignment by a supplier would undermine this selection process and could allow them to evade critical contractual obligations.
content.expert_insight: This justification is crucial for explaining Zebracorp's stance to suppliers. It highlights the inherent asymmetry in customer-supplier relationships regarding assignment, where the customer's vetting process is paramount.
content.justification: Explains why Zebracorp opposes mutual assignment rights for suppliers.
content.implication_company: Reinforces the importance of supplier due diligence and protects against risks associated with unvetted third-party contractors.
content.implication_supplier: Helps suppliers understand Zebracorp's position on assignment, potentially leading to more productive negotiations if the rationale is clear.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly provides this reasoning.
content.text: This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.

content.verbatim_text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's assignment right must not include joint liability for the assigned contract with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional, meaning Zebracorp will not be liable for the assignee's commitments and should achieve a clean exit from all liabilities under the assigned agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is a paramount requirement for Zebracorp to mitigate post-assignment liability. Remaining jointly liable negates much of the benefit of assignment. This point should be non-negotiable.
content.conditions: When assigning contracts.
content.justification: To ensure a clean exit from contractual obligations and avoid residual liability for commitments made by third-party assignees.
content.implication_company: Significantly reduces post-assignment liability and risk, providing a true transfer of obligations.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier will look solely to the assignee for performance and liability after Zebracorp's assignment.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states this as a requirement.
content.text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.

content.verbatim_text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent.
content.plain_text: When structuring corporate transactions like acquisitions, parties choose between asset sales (requiring specific contract assignments and due diligence) or acquiring the entire company (share capital purchase or merger). In a share acquisition or merger, contracts are generally not 'assigned' to a new legal entity; rather, the ownership of the existing entity changes, which typically does not require counterparty consent.
content.expert_insight: This explains the fundamental distinction between asset and share deals regarding contract transfer. It's a common misconception that a change of control always triggers assignment consent, but in share deals, the legal entity remains the same, so contracts continue with the same entity.
content.justification: Provides essential background for understanding 'assignment by operation of law' and its implications for corporate transactions.
content.implication_company: Informs strategic decisions on M&A structuring to minimize contract transfer complexities. Share acquisitions are generally simpler for contract continuity.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers need to understand that a change in their customer's ownership (share sale) does not typically grant them a right to consent to contract continuation.
content.source_insight: The text provides this detailed explanation.
content.text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent.

content.verbatim_text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party. The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.
content.plain_text: In most countries, acquisitions or mergers automatically transfer ('vest') all assets, liabilities, and contracts to the surviving or acquiring entity by 'operation of law,' without needing counterparty consent. However, parties can contractually agree that an ownership change (e.g., over 50% of shares) will require consent.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the 'operation of law' principle, which simplifies M&A. However, it also flags that contractual override clauses (change of control clauses) can negate this automatic transfer, making careful contract review essential.
content.justification: Explains the default legal position regarding contract transfer in mergers/acquisitions and how parties can modify it contractually.
content.implication_company: Relies on 'operation of law' for smoother M&A, but must be vigilant for contractual clauses that override this default.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may be bound to a new entity post-merger/acquisition unless a specific change of control clause is in place.
content.source_insight: The text describes the general legal principle and a common contractual counterpoint.
content.text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party. The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.

content.verbatim_text: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”.
content.plain_text: This clause states that any assignment of the agreement, whether direct, through a change in control, or by operation of law, is invalid without the other party's prior written consent.
content.expert_insight: This is a common, highly restrictive assignment clause that Zebracorp would generally want to avoid, as it explicitly overrides the 'operation of law' principle and requires consent even for indirect transfers.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of a restrictive assignment clause that includes 'change of control' and 'operation of law' provisions.
content.implication_company: Such a clause would severely restrict Zebracorp's flexibility in M&A and reorganizations, requiring consent for transfers that would otherwise be automatic.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers often include such clauses to maintain control over their contracting parties, even through indirect ownership changes.
content.source_insight: The text provides this as an example of a clause.
content.text: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's firm position is that assignment by operation of law should not require supplier consent. In most instances, any contractual language mandating such consent for transfers by operation of law should be rejected.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical policy for Zebracorp to ensure smooth corporate transactions. Clauses requiring consent for 'operation of law' transfers can significantly complicate and delay mergers and acquisitions.
content.conditions: Negotiating assignment clauses, especially those related to 'operation of law' or 'change of control'.
content.justification: Such provisions cause complications, impact timing, cost, and the ability to consummate smooth mergers or acquisitions.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp's ability to execute M&A and reorganizations efficiently without needing widespread supplier consents.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will not have a right to consent to contract transfers that occur due to Zebracorp's internal corporate restructuring.
content.source_insight: The text states this as Zebracorp's firm view and provides justification.
content.text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law.

content.verbatim_text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: For critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes assignment restrictions on suppliers, it's preferable to remove the clause entirely rather than agreeing to a mutual restriction that would limit Zebracorp. This non-mutuality can be justified by the customer-supplier asymmetry. To make it more acceptable, Zebracorp can allow suppliers to transfer by operation of law to non-competitors.
content.expert_insight: This provides a pragmatic negotiation strategy for sensitive contracts. It acknowledges the need for flexibility for Zebracorp while offering a concession to the supplier (transfer to non-competitors) to achieve a non-mutual outcome.
content.justification: To avoid restricting Zebracorp's own assignment flexibility while still managing supplier concerns in critical contracts.
content.implication_company: Maintains Zebracorp's flexibility in critical R&D areas while offering a potential compromise to suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may accept non-mutual clauses if they are allowed to transfer by operation of law to entities that are not direct competitors of Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text offers this as a strategic approach.
content.text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language. Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.
content.plain_text: Under UK law, assignment typically transfers only contract benefits. To transfer both benefits and burdens without residual liability, novation is generally required. For UK-governed agreements, it's advisable to specify both assignment and novation, potentially needing a separate novation agreement. While 'novation' is often misused in other jurisdictions, most recognize it as a contract transfer.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a critical distinction under UK law. In common law jurisdictions, assignment typically only transfers rights, not obligations, and does not release the assignor from liability. Novation is the mechanism for a full transfer (rights and obligations) with a release of the original party. This is a key point for contracts governed by UK law.
content.justification: Explains the legal distinction between assignment and novation, particularly under UK law, and its practical implications for contract drafting.
content.implication_company: When dealing with UK-governed contracts, Zebracorp must ensure proper novation for a clean transfer of both rights and obligations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers in UK-governed contracts need to understand the difference between assignment and novation to ensure proper transfer of their contractual position.
content.source_insight: The text provides this explanation and advice.
content.text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language. Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.

content.verbatim_text: Companies have the freedom to change the trade name that they use to conduct their business. When changing the name of the company, the registered legal entity which can be identified through each company’s individual registration number remains the same. These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes. Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”.
content.plain_text: A company name or registered address change is not considered an assignment as long as the underlying legal entity (identified by its registration number) remains the same. Therefore, no consent is required; a unilateral notification to the other party is sufficient. While clarifying the name change in future contract amendments is recommended (e.g., using '(formerly known as...)'), it's not strictly necessary.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies a common point of confusion. A name change is an administrative update, not a legal transfer of the contract. This distinction is important to avoid unnecessary consent processes.
content.justification: Clarifies that a company name/address change does not constitute an assignment, simplifying administrative processes.
content.implication_company: Reduces administrative burden as no consent is needed for name/address changes; simple notification suffices.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that a customer's name change does not alter the underlying contractual entity and does not require their consent.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly explains this situation.
content.text: Companies have the freedom to change the trade name that they use to conduct their business. When changing the name of the company, the registered legal entity which can be identified through each company’s individual registration number remains the same. These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes. Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”.

content.verbatim_text: “Except as otherwise provided in this [Agreement], neither party may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer this [Agreement], or any of its individual rights or obligations under this [Agreement], without the prior written approval of the other Party, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Any attempted assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer without the necessary approval is void. However, [Zebracorp] may, without the prior written consent of the [Supplier], unconditionally assign, novate, delegate or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations under this [Agreement], in whole, in part, or through a splitting of the [Agreement], to any Affiliate or to any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which this contract relates. As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement], and [Zebracorp] is unconditionally released and discharged from all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement]. [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.”
content.plain_text: This is Zebracorp's preferred assignment clause. It generally requires mutual written approval for assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, with consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed. However, Zebracorp retains the unilateral right to unconditionally assign, novate, delegate, or transfer all or part of its rights and obligations, or split the agreement, to an Affiliate or an acquirer of a relevant Zebracorp business line, without supplier consent. Upon such transfer, the assignee assumes all relevant rights and liabilities, and Zebracorp is unconditionally released. The supplier agrees to cooperate for a smooth transition.
content.expert_insight: This clause effectively implements all of Zebracorp's key objectives: general mutuality with a 'not unreasonably withheld' standard, but critical unilateral flexibility for Zebracorp for affiliates/business line acquirers, and a clean release from liability. The cooperation clause further ensures practical implementation.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of Zebracorp's preferred contractual language for assignment clauses, incorporating all key strategic objectives.
content.implication_company: Serves as a template for achieving desired assignment flexibility and liability release in contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers entering into contracts with this clause will grant Zebracorp significant unilateral assignment rights under specific conditions.
content.source_insight: The text provides this as 'Zebracorp’s preferred assignment clause'.

decision_content.verbatim_text: The view generally held by many US lawyers is that party promising to do ‘best efforts’ is required to do everything in its power to accomplish the target even if it bankrupts itself in the process. You should therefore expect in particular US based vendors to replace ‘best efforts’ with less onerous efforts standards such as in e.g. ‘commercial reasonable efforts’.
decision_content.plain_text: While many US lawyers interpret 'best efforts' as requiring a party to do everything possible, even to the point of bankruptcy, companies should anticipate US-based vendors to seek less stringent alternatives like 'commercially reasonable efforts' to reduce their burden.
decision_content.expert_insight: Companies should be prepared for US vendors to push back on 'best efforts' language, preferring 'commercially reasonable efforts' or similar, due to the potentially extreme interpretation of 'best efforts' under US legal perspectives. This negotiation point is critical for liability management and proactive strategy development.
decision_content.justification: The text describes a common US legal perspective on 'best efforts' and then provides direct advice on how to anticipate vendor behavior based on this, making it a tactical instruction for negotiation.
decision_content.implication_company: The company should anticipate US vendors pushing for 'commercially reasonable efforts' and be prepared to negotiate this point, understanding their underlying concern about the high bar of 'best efforts'. This allows for proactive negotiation strategy and awareness of vendor's likely stance, potentially saving time in discussions.
decision_content.implication_supplier: US-based vendors will likely seek to soften their commitment language, reflecting their understanding of 'best efforts' under US law, and may attempt to replace 'best efforts' with less demanding standards to mitigate perceived extreme liability.
decision_content.source_insight: The text highlights that under NY USA laws, 'best efforts' can be considered vague and not a binding enforceable obligation, but also presents a 'view generally held' by many US lawyers that 'best efforts' implies an extreme commitment. This dual perspective informs the tactical instruction to expect US vendors to propose less onerous standards.

decision_content.verbatim_text: As a rule of thumb we should be able to accept these less stringent variants whenever we would have been willing to accept the phrase ‘best efforts’.
decision_content.plain_text: As a general rule, less stringent variants of 'best efforts' (such as 'commercially reasonable efforts') can be accepted if the company would have been willing to accept 'best efforts' for that specific obligation.
decision_content.expert_insight: This guideline offers a pragmatic approach for negotiators: if the company is already comfortable with the inherent ambiguity and limited enforceability of 'best efforts' for a particular obligation, then accepting its less demanding variants (e.g., 'commercially reasonable efforts') should also be acceptable. This balances negotiation flexibility with risk, acknowledging that 'best efforts' itself is often vague and its variants may not significantly increase risk in such scenarios. However, this should always be weighed against the criticality of the obligation.
decision_content.conditions: Applicable when the company is already willing to accept the phrase 'best efforts' for a given obligation.
decision_content.justification: The text provides this as a 'rule of thumb' for accepting variants of 'best efforts' clauses, indicating a preferred position but with implied flexibility.
decision_content.implication_company: Provides a guideline for accepting certain effort standards, potentially streamlining negotiations when the commitment level is deemed sufficient, but requires careful consideration of the obligation's criticality.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find it easier to negotiate less stringent effort clauses if 'best efforts' was the initial ask, provided the company's baseline acceptance for 'best efforts' is met.
decision_content.source_insight: This is a direct recommendation for negotiation strategy, following the observation that 'best efforts' is often vague, implying that its variants might not be significantly worse in practice, *if* the company was already willing to accept the vagueness of 'best efforts.'

decision_content.verbatim_text: In all cases it is important to keep in mind that the phrase ‘best efforts’ together with all its variants are ultimately very vague and do not provide a firm commitment to meet the agreed requirement or obligation. Hence, we should, despite their prevalence, be careful in accepting such phrases.
decision_content.plain_text: Always remember that 'best efforts' and its variants are inherently vague and do not guarantee a firm commitment to meet contractual requirements. Exercise caution when accepting these phrases.
decision_content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental principle. The vagueness of 'best efforts' clauses makes them weak from an enforcement perspective. For critical obligations, seek specific, measurable commitments rather than relying on such ambiguous language.
decision_content.conditions: Applies to all instances where 'best efforts' or its variants are proposed.
decision_content.justification: Highlights the inherent vagueness and lack of firm commitment associated with these phrases, necessitating caution.
decision_content.implication_company: Accepting vague 'best efforts' clauses can lead to disputes and make it difficult to enforce performance, potentially impacting project success or quality standards. Exercising caution protects the company's interests.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Suppliers benefit from the reduced liability associated with vague 'best efforts' clauses, but they should also be aware that the company is advised to be cautious in accepting such terms and may push for clearer commitments.
decision_content.source_insight: The text provides a strong cautionary statement, emphasizing the lack of firm commitment from 'best efforts' clauses and advising careful acceptance.

decision_content.verbatim_text: As an example, when a supplier is hesitant as to whether it can comply with in e.g. all of the Zebracorp quality requirements or Zebracorp environmental requirements, it would be recommend to ask the supplier to identify which specific requirements the supplier is unable to meet and revise those as needed, instead of simply saying that the supplier will use best efforts or commercially reasonable effort to meet such requirements. The odds are that the supplier has no issues in committing itself to the majority of the requirements but only has reservations on some of the requirements. By requiring the supplier to identify those requirements that the supplier is unable to comply with, we often receive valuable information on the technical and other capabilities of the supplier products/solutions - information which would be lost if we merely accept the ‘best effort’ qualifier.
decision_content.plain_text: When a supplier expresses hesitation about meeting all Zebracorp quality or environmental requirements, it is recommended to ask them to identify the specific requirements they cannot meet and then revise those as needed. This approach is preferred over accepting a general 'best efforts' or 'commercially reasonable efforts' clause, as suppliers often have reservations only on a few requirements, and this process yields valuable information about their technical capabilities that would otherwise be lost.
decision_content.expert_insight: This is a crucial negotiation tactic that shifts the burden of specificity to the supplier. It ensures clearer, more enforceable commitments by preventing vague 'best efforts' clauses from undermining critical requirements. Furthermore, it provides valuable due diligence information about the supplier's actual capabilities and limitations, aiding in risk assessment and future sourcing decisions.
decision_content.justification: The text provides a detailed recommendation and rationale for a specific negotiation tactic, explicitly stating 'it would be recommend to ask' and explaining the benefits of this approach.
decision_content.implication_company: By proactively identifying specific non-compliance points, the company can secure firm commitments for most requirements, gain valuable insights into supplier capabilities, and avoid the vagueness of 'best efforts' clauses for critical obligations.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will be required to be more transparent about their capabilities and limitations, potentially leading to more specific and firm commitments rather than broad 'best efforts' clauses.
decision_content.source_insight: The instruction offers a practical alternative to accepting vague effort clauses, highlighting the benefit of gaining 'valuable information on the technical and other capabilities of the supplier products/solutions'.

decision_content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor does insist on using the phrase ‘commercially reasonable efforts’ in the context of obligations that should by their nature be fulfilled with a certain degree of firm commitment, a compromise can sometimes be found by specifying what the parties mean by this phrase. This can be done in e.g. by adding: “For the purposes hereof the term ‘commercially reasonable efforts’ means, with respect to a given goal, the efforts that a professional and diligent company would use and undertake so as to achieve that goal as expeditiously as possible and excludes any action or expenditure that would be unreasonably disproportionate or burdensome to achieve such goal”. The language of this type of a definition can obviously be negotiated so that the parties have a mutually acceptable understanding and agreement as to what is the required level of commitment.
decision_content.plain_text: If a supplier insists on 'commercially reasonable efforts' for obligations requiring firm commitment, a compromise can be reached by defining the phrase within the contract. For example, by adding a definition stating that 'commercially reasonable efforts' means the efforts a professional and diligent company would use to achieve a goal as expeditiously as possible, excluding unreasonably disproportionate or burdensome actions. This definition can be negotiated for mutual understanding.
decision_content.expert_insight: This is a crucial negotiation tactic and fallback strategy when a supplier insists on vague 'efforts' clauses for critical obligations. By defining 'commercially reasonable efforts' within the contract, the vague term is imbued with more specific, enforceable meaning, mitigating its inherent weakness. The provided example language offers a strong starting point for negotiation, allowing for a clearer benchmark for performance and reducing interpretative disputes.

decision_content.justification: Provides a specific negotiation tactic and example language for defining vague 'efforts' clauses when a supplier insists on them, aiming to create a more binding commitment.
decision_content.implication_company: Allows the company to accept 'commercially reasonable efforts' while still ensuring a higher, more defined standard of performance than the vague default, reducing risk and improving enforceability.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might accept a defined 'commercially reasonable efforts' if it provides clarity and avoids the perceived extreme of 'best efforts', while still limiting disproportionate burdens, increasing their accountability and clarity of their obligations.

decision_content.verbatim_text: Contract provisions that use the phrase ‘best efforts’ or one of its variants are often a source of confusion when negotiating agreements. Widely used variants to the phrase include ‘commercially reasonable efforts’, ‘commercially reasonable best efforts’, ‘good-faith efforts, ‘all reasonable efforts’ where the term ‘efforts’ is often replaced with the term ‘endeavours’. In each case the intent of the phrase is to remove the absolute duty or commitment to accomplish certain specific obligation or target. Understandably these phrases are often introduced by vendors in an attempt to soften their liability to meet some of the obligations that a purchasing agreement imposes on such vendors. As an example a product vendor may wish rephrase an obligation to meet Zebracorp quality requirements and standards to an obligation to make merely commercially reasonable efforts to meet such quality requirements and standards.
decision_content.plain_text: Contract provisions like 'best efforts' and its variants ('commercially reasonable efforts', 'good-faith efforts', 'all reasonable efforts') are common but confusing. Their purpose is to reduce an absolute commitment to an obligation, often used by vendors to lessen their liability in purchasing agreements, such as meeting quality standards.
decision_content.expert_insight: These clauses are frequently used by vendors to dilute their contractual obligations. Companies should be aware that accepting such language can significantly weaken the enforceability of commitments, transforming absolute duties into less stringent 'effort-based' undertakings.
decision_content.justification: The text explains the nature, variants, intent, and common application of 'best efforts' provisions, providing foundational context.
decision_content.implication_company: Accepting 'best efforts' clauses from vendors can reduce the enforceability of their obligations, potentially leading to lower quality or unmet standards without a clear breach of contract.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Vendors can use 'best efforts' clauses to soften their liability and avoid absolute commitments, providing more flexibility in meeting contractual obligations.
decision_content.source_insight: The text highlights the common practice of vendors introducing these phrases to mitigate their liability.

decision_content.verbatim_text: The legal meaning of these phrases varies from country to country. As an example under NY USA laws the phrase ‘best efforts’ basically only puts a good faith obligation on party do try to meet the prescribed obligation. Failure to accomplish such best efforts obligation would generally not be a breach of contract. This is because these phrases are considered too vague to create a binding enforceable obligation. This is in stark contrast to some of the common law countries where these phrases have more binding nature.
decision_content.plain_text: The legal interpretation of 'best efforts' clauses varies significantly by jurisdiction. For instance, under New York, USA laws, 'best efforts' typically implies only a good faith attempt, and failure to achieve the obligation is generally not a breach due to vagueness. This differs from common law countries where these phrases are often more binding.
decision_content.expert_insight: It is crucial to understand the governing law when interpreting 'best efforts' clauses, as their enforceability and meaning can drastically change based on jurisdiction. What is a mere good-faith attempt in one country might be a stringent obligation in another.
decision_content.justification: The text explicitly states the variation in legal meaning and provides a specific example for NY USA law versus common law countries.
decision_content.implication_company: The enforceability of 'best efforts' clauses depends heavily on the governing law. In jurisdictions like NY USA, these clauses may offer minimal protection, making it difficult to hold suppliers accountable for unmet obligations.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Suppliers operating under NY USA law may find 'best efforts' clauses to be less onerous, requiring only a good faith attempt rather than a guaranteed outcome, potentially reducing their liability.
decision_content.source_insight: The text directly contrasts the interpretation of 'best efforts' in different legal systems.

decisions.rationale: Consensus: Single candidate, classified as OTHER (INFO). Value Assessment: The plain_text is clear and self-sufficient, contextualizing 'this type of a definition' to 'such a definition for 'commercially reasonable efforts'' based on the preceding text in the source. Type-Specific Criteria: The classification as 'OTHER' with 'INFO' subtype is appropriate as it provides valuable contextual information regarding the negotiability of contractual definitions, rather than a strict rule or a formal definition. Utility Check: This finding is specific and highly useful for a human negotiator, emphasizing flexibility in defining terms like 'commercially reasonable efforts'.

content.verbatim_text: You should therefore expect in particular US based vendors to replace ‘best efforts’ with less onerous efforts standards such as in e.g. ‘commercial reasonable efforts’.
content.plain_text: Expect US-based vendors to propose less stringent effort standards, such as 'commercially reasonable efforts,' instead of 'best efforts'.
content.expert_insight: Anticipating negotiation tactics from US-based vendors, who often seek to soften commitment language due to specific legal interpretations of 'best efforts' in their jurisdiction, allows for proactive strategy development.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating with US-based vendors.
content.justification: This is a direct recommendation on what to expect from a specific type of vendor, guiding negotiation strategy.
content.implication_company: Allows for proactive negotiation strategy and awareness of vendor's likely stance, potentially saving time in discussions.
content.implication_supplier: US-based vendors will likely seek to soften their commitment language, reflecting their understanding of 'best efforts' under US law.
content.source_insight: The text highlights that under NY USA laws, 'best efforts' can be considered vague and not a binding enforceable obligation, leading US lawyers to advise against it.
content.text: You should therefore expect in particular US based vendors to replace ‘best efforts’ with less onerous efforts standards such as in e.g. ‘commercial reasonable efforts’.

content.verbatim_text: As a rule of thumb we should be able to accept these less stringent variants whenever we would have been willing to accept the phrase ‘best efforts’.
content.plain_text: As a general rule, we can accept less stringent effort standards (e.g., 'commercially reasonable efforts') if we would have otherwise accepted 'best efforts' for the specific obligation.
content.expert_insight: This provides a pragmatic approach, acknowledging that 'best efforts' itself is often vague. If the company was already willing to accept the inherent vagueness of 'best efforts,' then slightly less stringent variants might not significantly increase risk, but this should be balanced with the overall caution against vague terms.
content.conditions: Only applies when 'best efforts' would have been acceptable for the specific obligation.
content.justification: This is presented as a 'rule of thumb' for accepting certain contractual language, indicating a preferred position but with implied flexibility.
content.implication_company: Provides a guideline for accepting certain effort standards, potentially streamlining negotiations when the commitment level is deemed sufficient.
content.implication_supplier: May find it easier to negotiate less stringent effort clauses if 'best efforts' was the initial ask, provided the company's baseline acceptance is met.
content.source_insight: This guideline follows the observation that 'best efforts' is often vague, implying that its variants might not be significantly worse in practice, *if* the company was already willing to accept the vagueness of 'best efforts.'
content.text: As a rule of thumb we should be able to accept these less stringent variants whenever we would have been willing to accept the phrase ‘best efforts’.

content.verbatim_text: Hence, we should, despite their prevalence, be careful in accepting such phrases.
content.plain_text: We must be cautious when accepting 'best efforts' or its variants due to their inherent vagueness and lack of firm commitment.
content.expert_insight: Vague effort clauses can lead to significant disputes, make enforcement difficult, and expose the company to performance risks. This is a fundamental principle for protecting the company's interests and ensuring contractual obligations are clear and enforceable.
content.conditions: Applies to all instances where 'best efforts' or its variants are proposed.
content.justification: The text explicitly states these phrases 'do not provide a firm commitment' and advises 'be careful,' indicating a high-risk area that requires critical attention.
content.implication_company: Reduces the risk of unenforceable obligations and future disputes; requires diligence in contract review and negotiation.
content.implication_supplier: May face pushback on vague effort clauses and be required to provide firmer commitments or definitions.
content.source_insight: This is a direct consequence of the preceding statement that these phrases 'are ultimately very vague and do not provide a firm commitment to meet the agreed requirement or obligation.'
content.text: Hence, we should, despite their prevalence, be careful in accepting such phrases.

content.verbatim_text: As an example, when a supplier is hesitant as to whether it can comply with in e.g. all of the Zebracorp quality requirements or Zebracorp environmental requirements, it would be recommend to ask the supplier to identify which specific requirements the supplier is unable to meet and revise those as needed, instead of simply saying that the supplier will use best efforts or commercially reasonable effort to meet such requirements.
content.plain_text: If a supplier is hesitant about meeting specific requirements (e.g., quality, environmental), we should ask them to identify the exact requirements they cannot meet and then revise those specific points, rather than accepting a general 'best efforts' clause.
content.expert_insight: This strategy shifts the burden of specificity to the supplier, clarifies actual capabilities and limitations, and prevents broad, unenforceable commitments. It also provides valuable due diligence information about the supplier's technical capabilities.
content.conditions: Applies when a supplier expresses hesitancy regarding specific requirements (e.g., quality, environmental).
content.justification: This is a clear, actionable recommendation for a specific scenario ('it would be recommend to ask...') to avoid the pitfalls of vague effort clauses and gain valuable information.
content.implication_company: Gains clarity on supplier capabilities, ensures specific and enforceable commitments, and avoids vague obligations, leading to better contract outcomes.
content.implication_supplier: Must be transparent about limitations and negotiate specific deviations rather than relying on general effort clauses, increasing accountability.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states the benefit of this approach: 'we often receive valuable information on the technical and other capabilities of the supplier products/solutions - information which would be lost if we merely accept the ‘best effort’ qualifier.'
content.text: As an example, when a supplier is hesitant as to whether it can comply with in e.g. all of the Zebracorp quality requirements or Zebracorp environmental requirements, it would be recommend to ask the supplier to identify which specific requirements the supplier is unable to meet and revise those as needed, instead of simply saying that the supplier will use best efforts or commercially reasonable effort to meet such requirements.

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor does insist on using the phrase ‘commercially reasonable efforts’ in the context of obligations that should by their nature be fulfilled with a certain degree of firm commitment, a compromise can sometimes be found by specifying what the parties mean by this phrase.
content.plain_text: If a supplier insists on 'commercially reasonable efforts' for obligations requiring firm commitment, we can define the phrase within the contract to specify the expected level of effort and commitment.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial negotiation tactic to mitigate the vagueness of effort clauses when they cannot be avoided. Defining the terms provides clarity and enforceability, transforming a potentially weak commitment into a more robust and measurable one.
content.conditions: Applies when a supplier insists on 'commercially reasonable efforts' for obligations that inherently require a firm commitment.
content.justification: It offers a concrete solution ('a compromise can sometimes be found by specifying...') to address a common negotiation challenge, particularly for critical obligations.
content.implication_company: Allows for a negotiated solution to secure firmer commitments even when 'best efforts' variants are used, reducing risk and improving enforceability.
content.implication_supplier: Must agree to a specific definition of 'commercially reasonable efforts,' increasing their accountability and clarity of their obligations.
content.source_insight: The text provides an example definition, emphasizing that 'the language of this type of a definition can obviously be negotiated so that the parties have a mutually acceptable understanding and agreement as to what is the required level of commitment.'
content.text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor does insist on using the phrase ‘commercially reasonable efforts’ in the context of obligations that should by their nature be fulfilled with a certain degree of firm commitment, a compromise can sometimes be found by specifying what the parties mean by this phrase.

content.verbatim_text: Widely used variants to the phrase include ‘commercially reasonable efforts’, ‘commercially reasonable best efforts’, ‘good-faith efforts, ‘all reasonable efforts’ where the term ‘efforts’ is often replaced with the term ‘endeavours’.

content.expert_insight: Understanding these variants is crucial as they each carry slightly different legal interpretations and implications, though all generally aim to soften an absolute commitment.

content.text: Widely used variants to the phrase include ‘commercially reasonable efforts’, ‘commercially reasonable best efforts’, ‘good-faith efforts, ‘all reasonable efforts’ where the term ‘efforts’ is often replaced with the term ‘endeavours’.

content.verbatim_text: In each case the intent of the phrase is to remove the absolute duty or commitment to accomplish certain specific obligation or target. Understandably these phrases are often introduced by vendors in an attempt to soften their liability to meet some of the obligations that a purchasing agreement imposes on such vendors.
content.plain_text: The purpose of 'best efforts' and its variants is to avoid an absolute commitment, thereby softening a party's liability. Vendors often introduce these phrases to reduce their obligations in purchasing agreements.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies the strategic motivation behind using these clauses, primarily as a liability mitigation tool for the performing party. It's a key insight into supplier negotiation tactics.
content.justification: Explains the fundamental intent and common use case of these clauses, particularly from a vendor's perspective.
content.implication_company: We should be wary when suppliers propose these clauses, as their intent is to reduce their firm commitment and potential liability.
content.implication_supplier: These phrases are a standard tool for suppliers to manage and limit their contractual exposure and obligations.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states the 'intent' and links it to 'soften their liability', providing a clear strategic context.
content.text: In each case the intent of the phrase is to remove the absolute duty or commitment to accomplish certain specific obligation or target. Understandably these phrases are often introduced by vendors in an attempt to soften their liability to meet some of the obligations that a purchasing agreement imposes on such vendors.

content.verbatim_text: As an example a product vendor may wish rephrase an obligation to meet Zebracorp quality requirements and standards to an obligation to make merely commercially reasonable efforts to meet such quality requirements and standards.
content.plain_text: For instance, a product vendor might change an obligation to 'meet Zebracorp quality requirements' to 'make commercially reasonable efforts to meet such quality requirements'.
content.expert_insight: This concrete example illustrates how a supplier might attempt to dilute a firm commitment, providing a practical scenario for our negotiators to recognize.
content.justification: Provides a clear, specific example of how a 'best efforts' variant might be used to alter a contractual obligation.
content.implication_company: This shows how a supplier might attempt to weaken our quality requirements, which we must resist or clarify.
content.implication_supplier: This is a common tactic for suppliers to manage the risk of failing to meet stringent quality standards.
content.source_insight: The use of 'As an example' clearly marks this as an illustrative scenario.
content.text: As an example a product vendor may wish rephrase an obligation to meet Zebracorp quality requirements and standards to an obligation to make merely commercially reasonable efforts to meet such quality requirements and standards.

content.verbatim_text: The legal meaning of these phrases varies from country to country. As an example under NY USA laws the phrase ‘best efforts’ basically only puts a good faith obligation on party do try to meet the prescribed obligation. Failure to accomplish such best efforts obligation would generally not be a breach of contract. This is because these phrases are considered too vague to create a binding enforceable obligation. This is in stark contrast to some of the common law countries where these phrases have more binding nature.
content.plain_text: The legal interpretation of 'best efforts' clauses differs significantly by jurisdiction. For example, under New York, USA law, 'best efforts' is often seen as a good faith obligation to try, and failure to achieve the goal is not necessarily a breach due to its vagueness. This contrasts with some common law countries where these phrases are more binding.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical piece of information for international negotiations. The governing law clause will heavily influence the enforceability of 'best efforts' provisions, making jurisdiction-specific legal advice essential.
content.justification: Explains the jurisdictional differences in interpreting 'best efforts' clauses, providing crucial legal context.
content.implication_company: We must consider the governing law of the contract when evaluating 'best efforts' clauses, as their enforceability varies significantly.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers operating internationally will be aware of these jurisdictional differences and may leverage them in negotiations.
content.source_insight: Highlights a key legal nuance: the enforceability of these clauses is not universal and depends on the specific legal framework.
content.text: The legal meaning of these phrases varies from country to country. As an example under NY USA laws the phrase ‘best efforts’ basically only puts a good faith obligation on party do try to meet the prescribed obligation. Failure to accomplish such best efforts obligation would generally not be a breach of contract. This is because these phrases are considered too vague to create a binding enforceable obligation. This is in stark contrast to some of the common law countries where these phrases have more binding nature.

content.verbatim_text: The view generally held by many US lawyers is that party promising to do ‘best efforts’ is required to do everything in its power to accomplish the target even if it bankrupts itself in the process. You should therefore expect in particular US based vendors to replace ‘best efforts’ with less onerous efforts standards such as in e.g. ‘commercial reasonable efforts’.
content.plain_text: Many US lawyers believe 'best efforts' implies doing everything possible, even to the point of bankruptcy. Therefore, expect US vendors to propose less stringent standards like 'commercially reasonable efforts'.
content.expert_insight: This provides a dual insight: the perceived high bar of 'best efforts' in the US (despite the earlier NY law example, this represents a common *negotiation stance* or *worst-case interpretation*) and a direct tactical prediction for negotiations with US-based suppliers. We should anticipate this pushback.
content.justification: Provides insight into US legal interpretation and offers a direct prediction of vendor behavior, which is a tactical consideration for negotiations.
content.implication_company: We should anticipate US vendors pushing for 'commercially reasonable efforts' and be prepared to negotiate this point, understanding their underlying concern about the high bar of 'best efforts'.
content.implication_supplier: US suppliers will likely attempt to replace 'best efforts' with less demanding standards to mitigate perceived extreme liability.
content.source_insight: The text presents a 'view generally held' which might differ from strict legal interpretation in all US states (as per the NY example), but is a relevant negotiation reality. The 'You should therefore expect' clearly indicates a tactical instruction.
content.text: The view generally held by many US lawyers is that party promising to do ‘best efforts’ is required to do everything in its power to accomplish the target even if it bankrupts itself in the process. You should therefore expect in particular US based vendors to replace ‘best efforts’ with less onerous efforts standards such as in e.g. ‘commercial reasonable efforts’.

content.plain_text: As a general guideline, we can accept less stringent variants of 'best efforts' if we would have been willing to accept 'best efforts' itself.
content.expert_insight: This provides internal guidance on when to concede to a supplier's request for a less onerous efforts standard. It implies that if 'best efforts' was already deemed acceptable (i.e., not a critical, absolute commitment), then its weaker variants should also be acceptable.
content.justification: Offers a practical rule of thumb for internal decision-making regarding the acceptance of 'efforts' clauses.
content.implication_company: This provides a clear internal guideline for negotiators, streamlining decisions on 'efforts' clauses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might find it easier to get 'commercially reasonable efforts' accepted if 'best efforts' was already on the table.
content.source_insight: The phrase 'As a rule of thumb we should be able to accept' directly indicates an internal instruction.
content.text: As a rule of thumb we should be able to accept these less stringent variants whenever we would have been willing to accept the phrase ‘best efforts’.

content.verbatim_text: In all cases it is important to keep in mind that the phrase ‘best efforts’ together with all its variants are ultimately very vague and do not provide a firm commitment to meet the agreed requirement or obligation. Hence, we should, despite their prevalence, be careful in accepting such phrases.
content.plain_text: Always remember that 'best efforts' and its variants are vague and do not guarantee a firm commitment. Therefore, we should be cautious about accepting them.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental warning. Despite their common use, these clauses fundamentally weaken commitments. Our default stance should be skepticism and a preference for more definitive language.
content.justification: Emphasizes the inherent vagueness and lack of firm commitment associated with 'efforts' clauses, providing a general directive for caution.
content.implication_company: We must exercise caution and seek clearer, more binding language whenever possible to ensure our requirements are met.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers benefit from the vagueness, as it reduces their exposure to strict performance obligations.

content.verbatim_text: As an example, when a supplier is hesitant as to whether it can comply with in e.g. all of the Zebracorp quality requirements or Zebracorp environmental requirements, it would be recommend to ask the supplier to identify which specific requirements the supplier is unable to meet and revise those as needed, instead of simply saying that the supplier will use best efforts or commercially reasonable effort to meet such requirements.

content.expert_insight: This is a highly effective negotiation tactic. It forces the supplier to be specific, identifies potential areas of non-compliance early, and prevents a blanket 'best efforts' clause from undermining critical requirements. It also provides valuable due diligence information.
content.justification: Provides a specific, actionable strategy for dealing with supplier hesitancy regarding compliance, offering a superior alternative to accepting vague 'efforts' clauses.

content.verbatim_text: The odds are that the supplier has no issues in committing itself to the majority of the requirements but only has reservations on some of the requirements. By requiring the supplier to identify those requirements that the supplier is unable to comply with, we often receive valuable information on the technical and other capabilities of the supplier products/solutions - information which would be lost if we merely accept the ‘best effort’ qualifier.
content.plain_text: Suppliers usually have issues with only a few requirements, not the majority. By making them identify specific non-compliant requirements, we gain valuable insights into their technical capabilities, which would be lost if we just accepted a 'best effort' clause.
content.expert_insight: This explains the strategic benefit of the previous tactic. It's not just about avoiding vague language, but actively extracting crucial intelligence about a supplier's true capabilities and limitations, which is vital for risk assessment and future planning.
content.justification: Provides the rationale and benefits behind the tactic of asking suppliers to identify specific non-compliant requirements.
content.implication_company: This approach yields critical intelligence about supplier capabilities, aiding in risk management and future sourcing decisions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are compelled to reveal their limitations, which can inform our assessment of their suitability.
content.source_insight: This section elaborates on the 'why' behind the recommended tactic, providing context and justification.
content.text: The odds are that the supplier has no issues in committing itself to the majority of the requirements but only has reservations on some of the requirements. By requiring the supplier to identify those requirements that the supplier is unable to comply with, we often receive valuable information on the technical and other capabilities of the supplier products/solutions - information which would be lost if we merely accept the ‘best effort’ qualifier.

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor does insist on using the phrase ‘commercially reasonable efforts’ in the context of obligations that should by their nature be fulfilled with a certain degree of firm commitment, a compromise can sometimes be found by specifying what the parties mean by this phrase. This can be done in e.g. by adding: “For the purposes hereof the term ‘commercially reasonable efforts’ means, with respect to a given goal, the efforts that a professional and diligent company would use and undertake so as to achieve that goal as expeditiously as possible and excludes any action or expenditure that would be unreasonably disproportionate or burdensome to achieve such goal”. The language of this type of a definition can obviously be negotiated so that the parties have a mutually acceptable understanding and agreement as to what is the required level of commitment.
content.plain_text: If a supplier insists on 'commercially reasonable efforts' for obligations requiring firm commitment, a compromise can be to define the phrase. For example, by stating it means 'efforts a professional and diligent company would use to achieve the goal expeditiously, excluding disproportionate or burdensome actions/expenditures.' This definition can be negotiated.
content.expert_insight: This is an excellent fallback tactic when a supplier is unyielding. By defining 'commercially reasonable efforts,' we can imbue a vague term with more specific, enforceable meaning, thereby mitigating some of its inherent weakness. The example language provides a strong starting point for negotiation.
content.justification: Provides a specific negotiation tactic and example language for defining vague 'efforts' clauses when a supplier insists on them, aiming to create a more binding commitment.
content.implication_company: This allows us to accept 'commercially reasonable efforts' while still ensuring a higher, more defined standard of performance than the vague default.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might accept a defined 'commercially reasonable efforts' if it provides clarity and avoids the perceived extreme of 'best efforts', while still limiting disproportionate burdens.
content.source_insight: The text offers a 'compromise' solution and provides explicit 'example' language, making it a clear tactical instruction.

This can be done in e.g. by adding: “For the purposes hereof the term ‘commercially reasonable efforts’ means, with respect to a given goal, the efforts that a professional and diligent company would use and undertake so as to achieve that goal as expeditiously as possible and excludes any action or expenditure that would be unreasonably disproportionate or burdensome to achieve such goal”. The language of this type of a definition can obviously be negotiated so that the parties have a mutually acceptable understanding and agreement as to what is the required level of commitment.

content.expert_insight: This definition serves as a compromise when a firm commitment is difficult to obtain. It attempts to provide more clarity than 'best efforts' but still allows for negotiation on what constitutes 'unreasonably disproportionate or burdensome' actions or expenditures, requiring parties to agree on the specific level of commitment.
